Q: 1. Display the first 5 rows of the "Customer" table.
A:
You can achieve that in multiple ways depending on your preferred SQL dialect and desired output format. Here are three options for the AdventureWorks2012 database:

1. Using SELECT TOP (SQL Server only):

SQL
SELECT TOP 5 *FROM Customer;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This concisely displays the first 5 rows of all columns in the "Customer" table.

2. Using LIMIT (MySQL and similar dialects):

SQL
SELECT *FROM CustomerLIMIT 5;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This achieves the same result as the previous option, but using the LIMIT clause instead of TOP.

3. Using ROW_NUMBER (Oracle and SQL Server):

SQL
SELECT *FROM (  SELECT *, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY CustomerID) AS RowNum  FROM Customer) AS cWHERE c.RowNum <= 5;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This option assigns a row number to each customer and then filters the result to only include the first 5 rows based on that assigned number.

Choose the option that best suits your preferred dialect and desired output format. All three options will successfully display the first 5 rows of the "Customer" table in your AdventureWorks2012 database.

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks!

Q: 2. Find the total number of rows in the "Product" table.
A:
Here are two ways to find the total number of rows in the "Product" table of your AdventureWorks2012 database:

1. Using the COUNT function:

SQL
SELECT COUNT(*) AS TotalProductsFROM Production.Product;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This query uses the COUNT function with the asterisk (*) wildcard to count all rows in the "Product" table and returns the result as a single column named TotalProducts.

2. Using the sys.tables and sys.indexes system views:

SQL
SELECT SUM(t.rows) AS TotalProductsFROM sys.tables tINNER JOIN sys.indexes i ON t.object_id = i.object_idWHERE t.name = "Product"AND i.index_id IN (0, 1); // Include primary and clustered index only
Use code with caution. Learn more

This option relies on system views to access internal database information. sys.tables stores information about tables, including the row count (in the rows column), and sys.indexes provides details about indexes. The query filters to the "Product" table and includes both the primary key and clustered index (if present) to ensure accurate counting.

Both methods will give you the same result: the total number of rows in the "Product" table. Choose the option that best suits your preference and database platform capabilities.

If you have any other questions or need help with your SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database, feel free to ask!

Q: 3. Retrieve all columns from the "SalesOrderHeader" table.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to retrieve all columns from the "SalesOrderHeader" table in the AdventureWorks2012 database:

SQL
SELECT *FROM Sales.SalesOrderHeader;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • SELECT *: This clause instructs the database to fetch all columns from the specified table.
  • FROM Sales.SalesOrderHeader: This clause designates the "SalesOrderHeader" table within the "Sales" schema as the source of the data.

Key points:

  • Schema specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name ("Sales" in this case) as part of the table name.
  • Column order: The columns will appear in the result set in the order they are defined within the table structure.
  • Data volume: Consider the potential amount of data returned, as retrieving all columns might involve a large result set. If you only need specific columns, list them explicitly instead of using *.

Additional considerations:

  • Filtering and sorting: You can add a WHERE clause to filter specific rows and an ORDER BY clause to arrange the results in a desired order.
  • Performance optimization: For large tables, consider using indexing strategies and limiting the columns retrieved to enhance performance.

I"m here to help if you have further questions or need assistance with other SQL tasks!

Q: 4. Show unique values from the "ProductCategory" column in the "Product" table.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to display unique values from the "ProductCategory" column in the "Product" table:

SQL
SELECT DISTINCT ProductCategoryFROM Production.Product;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • SELECT DISTINCT: This clause instructs the database to retrieve only distinct (unique) values from the specified column.
  • ProductCategory: This specifies the column from which you want to extract the unique values.
  • FROM Production.Product: This indicates the source table for the data.

Key points:

  • Schema specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name ("Production" in this case) as part of the table name.
  • Result organization: The unique values will be presented in a single column, one value per row.
  • Case sensitivity: The distinctness will be determined based on the case sensitivity of your database system. If case doesn"t matter, you might consider converting values to a common case using functions like UPPER or LOWER.

Additional considerations:

  • Ordering results: You can add an ORDER BY clause to arrange the unique values in a specific order, such as alphabetically.
  • Combining with other columns: You can include additional columns in the SELECT clause to view other information alongside the unique product categories.

I"m ready to assist with any further SQL tasks you may have!

Q: 5. Retrieve the product names and prices from the "Product" table.
A:
There are two ways to retrieve the product names and prices from the "Product" table in the AdventureWorks2012 database, depending on how you want the prices displayed:

1. Show product names and list prices:

SQL
SELECT Name, ListPriceFROM Production.Product;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This query selects the Name and ListPrice columns from the Product table. ListPrice represents the manufacturer"s suggested retail price.

2. Show product names and formatted prices:

SQL
SELECT Name, FORMAT(ListPrice, "c", "en-US") AS "FormattedPrice"FROM Production.Product;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This query also selects the Name and ListPrice columns, but it additionally:

  • Uses the FORMAT function to convert the ListPrice into a currency format.
  • Specifies the format code "c", which represents currency, and the culture "en-US" for US dollar formatting.

Choose the option that best suits your needs for displaying prices. Both queries will retrieve the product names and their corresponding prices from the "Product" table.

Remember to include the schema name (Production) if necessary based on your database platform.

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 6. Display customers from the "Customer" table whose last name is "Johnson".
A:
Here"s the SQL query to display customers from the "Customer" table whose last name is "Johnson":

SQL
SELECT *FROM CustomerWHERE LastName = "Johnson";
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • SELECT *: This retrieves all columns from the "Customer" table. You can replace it with specific column names if you only need certain information about the customers.
  • FROM Customer: This specifies the source table for the data.
  • WHERE LastName = "Johnson": This filters the results to include only customers where the "LastName" column value is exactly "Johnson".

Key Points:

  • Case sensitivity: Depending on your database platform, the comparison might be case-sensitive. Consider using functions like UPPER or LOWER on the "LastName" column and "Johnson" string for consistent matching across cases.
  • Partial matches: If you want to search for customers with last names containing "Johnson", you can use wildcard characters like "%Johnson%" in the WHERE clause.
  • Additional filtering: You can combine the WHERE clause with other conditions to further refine the customer list. For example, you can filter by customer city, state, or other relevant data points.

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 7. List the product names and their corresponding categories from the "Product" and "ProductCategory" tables.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to list the product names and their corresponding categories from the "Product" and "ProductCategory" tables:

SQL
SELECT p.Name AS ProductName, pc.Name AS CategoryNameFROM Production.Product pINNER JOIN Production.ProductCategory pcON p.ProductCategoryID = pc.ProductCategoryID;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • SELECT p.Name AS ProductName, pc.Name AS CategoryName: This clause selects the product names and category names, using aliases for clarity.
  • FROM Production.Product p: This indicates the "Product" table as the primary source, with an alias "p" for brevity.
  • INNER JOIN Production.ProductCategory pc: This joins the "ProductCategory" table (aliased as "pc") with the "Product" table.
  • ON p.ProductCategoryID = pc.ProductCategoryID: This specifies the joining condition, ensuring that only products and categories with matching IDs are linked.

Key points:

  • Schema specification: Ensure you include the correct schema names (Production) if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Aliases: Using aliases like "p" and "pc" improves readability and clarity, especially when working with multiple tables.
  • Join type: The "INNER JOIN" returns only rows where matching values exist in both tables, ensuring complete information for each product-category pair.

Additional tips:

  • Filtering: You can add a WHERE clause to filter the results based on specific criteria (e.g., select products within a certain price range or from a particular category).
  • Ordering: You can use ORDER BY to arrange the results in a desired order (e.g., alphabetically by product name or category).

I"m ready to assist with any further SQL tasks you may have!

Q: 8. Find the average order quantity from the "SalesOrderDetail" table.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to calculate the average order quantity from the "SalesOrderDetail" table:

SQL
SELECT AVG(OrderQty) AS AverageOrderQuantityFROM Sales.SalesOrderDetail;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • SELECT AVG(OrderQty) AS AverageOrderQuantity: This calculates the average of the "OrderQty" column and presents it as a single value named "AverageOrderQuantity".
  • FROM Sales.SalesOrderDetail: This specifies the "SalesOrderDetail" table as the source of the data.

Key points:

  • Schema specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name ("Sales" in this case) as part of the table name if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Aggregate function: The AVG function is used to compute the average value of a numerical column.
  • Alias: The AS keyword creates a more descriptive alias for the calculated average, making the result easier to interpret.

Additional considerations:

  • Filtering: You can add a WHERE clause to calculate the average for a specific subset of orders, such as orders within a certain date range or for a particular product category.
  • Grouping: If you need to find the average order quantity for different groups (e.g., by product category or customer), you can use the GROUP BY clause in conjunction with AVG.

I"m ready to assist with any further SQL tasks you may have on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 9. Sort the "Product" table based on the "Name" column in descending order.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to sort the "Product" table based on the "Name" column in descending order:

SQL
SELECT *FROM Production.ProductORDER BY Name DESC;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • SELECT *: This fetches all columns from the "Product" table. You can replace it with specific column names if you only need certain data.
  • FROM Production.Product: This indicates the source table for the data.
  • ORDER BY Name DESC: This arranges the results in descending order based on the "Name" column. The DESC keyword specifies descending order.

Key points:

  • Schema specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name (Production) as part of the table name if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Ordering direction: The DESC keyword designates descending order. For ascending order, you"d use ASC (although it"s the default, so it"s often omitted).
  • Multiple sorting: You can specify multiple columns for sorting by separating them with commas within the ORDER BY clause. The first column takes priority, and subsequent columns are used for further sorting within the groups of the first column.

Feel free to ask if you have any other questions or need help with other SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 10. Count the number of distinct product names in the "Product" table.
A:
There are two ways to count the number of distinct product names in the "Product" table, depending on whether you want to perform case-sensitive or case-insensitive counting:

1. Case-sensitive counting:

SQL
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT Name) AS DistinctProductNamesFROM Production.Product;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This query uses the COUNT(DISTINCT) function with the Name column to count the number of unique values in the Name column, considering case sensitivity.

2. Case-insensitive counting:

SQL
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT UPPER(Name)) AS DistinctProductNamesFROM Production.Product;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This query uses the UPPER function to convert all Name values to uppercase before applying the COUNT(DISTINCT) function. This ensures that case variations are ignored, resulting in a case-insensitive count.

Key points:

  • Schema specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name (Production) as part of the table name if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Alias: Using an alias like DistinctProductNames for the count makes the result more descriptive.
  • Case sensitivity: Choose the appropriate query based on whether you want to treat uppercase and lowercase characters in product names differently.

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 11. Show orders from the "SalesOrderHeader" table with a total due amount greater than 200.
A:
Here are two ways to display orders from the "SalesOrderHeader" table with a total due amount greater than 200:

1. Using the TotalDue column directly:

SQL
SELECT *FROM Sales.SalesOrderHeaderWHERE TotalDue > 200;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • This query selects all columns (*) from the SalesOrderHeader table.
  • The WHERE clause filters the results to include only orders where the TotalDue column value is greater than 200.
  • This method assumes you have a TotalDue column that already reflects the final due amount after any discounts or taxes.

2. Calculating the total due on the fly:

SQL
SELECT SalesOrderID,        CustomerID,        OrderDate,        SubTotal,        TaxAmt,        Freight,       SubTotal + TaxAmt + Freight AS TotalDueFROM Sales.SalesOrderHeaderHAVING TotalDue > 200;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • This query selects specific columns from the SalesOrderHeader table.
  • It calculates the total due on the fly by summing the SubTotal, TaxAmt, and Freight columns in the HAVING clause.
  • The HAVING clause then filters the results to include only orders where the calculated TotalDue is greater than 200.
  • This method is useful if your TotalDue column might not be immediately available or updated regularly.

Note:

  • Both queries assume you"re using the Sales schema name. Verify and adjust if necessary based on your database platform.
  • You can further customize the queries to include additional columns from the SalesOrderHeader table based on your needs.

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 12. Retrieve the top 3 most expensive products from the "Product" table.
A:
There are two main ways to retrieve the top 3 most expensive products from the "Product" table in the AdventureWorks2012 database, depending on your preferred method and database platform:

1. Using TOP (SQL Server):

SQL
SELECT TOP 3 *FROM Production.ProductORDER BY ListPrice DESC;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • This query uses the TOP keyword to specify the number of desired rows (3 in this case).
  • It selects all columns (*) from the Product table.
  • The ORDER BY clause sorts the results in descending order based on the ListPrice column, placing the most expensive products first.

2. Using LIMIT (MySQL and similar dialects):

SQL
SELECT *FROM Production.ProductORDER BY ListPrice DESCLIMIT 3;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • This query uses the LIMIT clause to specify the number of desired rows (3 in this case).
  • Similar to the previous option, it selects all columns and sorts by ListPrice in descending order.

Important notes:

  • Ensure you replace Production.Product with the correct schema name if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Consider replacing * with specific column names if only certain product information is needed.
  • Some platforms might have alternative methods for achieving the same result, so consult your specific database documentation for optimal approaches.

Bonus: To include both the product name and price in the result, you can modify the queries slightly:

  • With TOP (SQL Server):
SQL
SELECT TOP 3 Name, ListPriceFROM Production.ProductORDER BY ListPrice DESC;
Use code with caution. Learn more
  • With LIMIT (MySQL and similar dialects):
SQL
SELECT Name, ListPriceFROM Production.ProductORDER BY ListPrice DESCLIMIT 3;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Q: 13. Calculate the total sales amount for each order in the "SalesOrderHeader" table.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to calculate the total sales amount for each order in the "SalesOrderHeader" table:

SQL
SELECT SalesOrderID, SUM(LineTotal) AS TotalSalesAmountFROM Sales.SalesOrderHeader sohJOIN Sales.SalesOrderDetail sod ON soh.SalesOrderID = sod.SalesOrderIDGROUP BY SalesOrderID;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  1. Joining Tables:

    • The query begins by joining the "SalesOrderHeader" table (aliased as "soh") with the "SalesOrderDetail" table (aliased as "sod") using a JOIN clause. This links the two tables based on the "SalesOrderID" column, allowing us to access information from both tables simultaneously.

  2. Calculating Total Sales Amount:

    • The SUM(LineTotal) function aggregates the "LineTotal" values for each order, calculating the total sales amount for each unique "SalesOrderID".

  3. Grouping and Selecting:

    • The GROUP BY SalesOrderID clause instructs the database to group the results by "SalesOrderID", ensuring that the total sales amount is calculated for each individual order.
    • The SELECT clause specifies which columns to display in the output, including the "SalesOrderID" and the calculated "TotalSalesAmount".

Key Points:

  • Schema Specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name ("Sales" in this case) as part of the table names if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Aliasing: Using aliases for tables ("soh" and "sod") can improve readability and clarity, especially when working with multiple tables.
  • Aggregate Function: The SUM function is used to compute the total of a numerical column within each group.
  • Grouping: The GROUP BY clause is essential for grouping the results based on a specific column and performing calculations within those groups.

Feel free to ask if you have any other questions or need help with additional SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 15. Filter the "Product" table to display products with a price less than 100.
A:
There are two main ways to filter the "Product" table to display products with a price less than 100, depending on your preferred syntax and database platform:

1. Using WHERE clause:

SQL
SELECT *FROM Production.ProductWHERE ListPrice < 100;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This option selects all columns (*) from the "Product" table where the ListPrice is less than 100. Ensure you update the Production.Product schema name if necessary based on your platform.

2. Using HAVING clause (MySQL and similar dialects):

SQL
SELECT *FROM Production.ProductHAVING ListPrice < 100;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This option also selects all columns and filters based on price, but utilizes the HAVING clause which is typically used after aggregate functions. While not strictly necessary in this case, it might be a preferred syntax in specific circumstances depending on your platform or context.

Both options will successfully display products with prices below 100. You can further customize the query by:

  • Specifying specific columns to retrieve instead of *.
  • Sorting the results by price or another column using ORDER BY.
  • Applying additional filters using further conditions in the WHERE clause.

Q: 16. Update the "Product" table to set the price to 75 for products with a price greater than 75.
A:
There are two ways to update the "Product" table to set the price to 75 for products with a price greater than 75, depending on your preferred syntax:

1. Using UPDATE with WHERE clause:

SQL
UPDATE Production.ProductSET ListPrice = 75WHERE ListPrice > 75;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This option explicitly sets the ListPrice to 75 for all products where the current ListPrice is greater than 75. Remember to adjust the schema name (Production.Product) if necessary for your platform.

2. Using UPDATE with conditional expression:

SQL
UPDATE Production.ProductSET ListPrice = CASE WHEN ListPrice > 75 THEN 75 ELSE ListPrice END;
Use code with caution. Learn more

This option utilizes a CASE statement to update the price dynamically. For products with a price above 75, it sets it to 75. Otherwise, it leaves the original price unchanged.

Both methods will achieve the desired update. Choose the option that best suits your preference or aligns with your specific database platform"s recommendations.

Important notes:

  • This update directly modifies data in the table. Ensure you have proper backups or understand the potential impact before executing it.
  • Consider including an additional ORDER BY clause if the update order matters for any reason.

If you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks on the AdventureWorks2012 database, feel free to ask!

Q: 17. Insert a new product into the "Product" table.
A:
Here"s an example SQL query to insert a new product into the "Product" table, using example data:

SQL
INSERT INTO Production.Product (Name, ProductNumber, ListPrice, ProductCategoryID)VALUES ("New Product Example", "NP-12345", 99.99, 7);
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  • INSERT INTO: This clause initiates the insertion of data into a table.
  • Production.Product: This specifies the target table for the insertion (replace with the correct schema name if needed).
  • (Name, ProductNumber, ListPrice, ProductCategoryID): These are the specific columns into which values will be inserted.
  • VALUES: This keyword introduces the values to be inserted.
  • ("New Product Example", "NP-12345", 99.99, 7): These are the actual values for each corresponding column.

Key Points:

  • Schema Name: Verify and adjust the schema name (Production) as needed for your database platform.
  • Column Order: Ensure the values are listed in the same order as the columns in the table.
  • Required Columns: Check which columns are mandatory in your table and include values for them.
  • Additional Columns: If you have more columns in your table, add them to the INSERT INTO clause and provide corresponding values.
  • Executing in Your Database: You"ll need to execute this query within your database environment to insert the new product.

Example Data:

The example data used here includes:

  • Name: New Product Example
  • ProductNumber: NP-12345
  • ListPrice: 99.99
  • ProductCategoryID: 7 (assuming a valid category ID in your database)

Replace these with the actual values for the product you want to insert.

Additional Information:

If you have other relevant columns in your "Product" table, incorporate them into the query and provide appropriate values.

Q: 18. Delete all products from the "Product" table with a price greater than 200.
A:
I understand you want to delete products from the "Product" table based on their price. However, it"s crucial to be careful when deleting data, especially large amounts, as it"s irreversible and could have unintended consequences.

Before proceeding, consider these alternatives:

1. Filtering instead of deleting: If you only need to exclude certain products from your results, consider filtering them based on price using WHERE clauses in your queries instead of deleting them permanently.

2. Archiving instead of deleting: If you need to remove these products from active use but might need them later, consider archiving them to a separate table instead of deleting them completely.

3. Double-checking the criteria: Ensure you"re confident about the price threshold (200) and that deleting products above it is the intended action.

If you"re still sure about permanently deleting the products, here"s the SQL query to achieve that:

SQL
DELETE FROM Production.ProductWHERE ListPrice > 200;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Note: Remember to replace Production.Product with the correct schema name if necessary for your platform.

Execute this query with caution! Ensure you have proper backups or understand the potential impact before running it.

I recommend revisiting your goal and exploring alternative solutions before permanently deleting data. If you can share more context about your desired outcome, I can help you find a safer and more appropriate approach.

Q: 19. Retrieve the average order quantity for each product from the "SalesOrderDetail" table.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to retrieve the average order quantity for each product from the "SalesOrderDetail" table:

SQL
SELECT ProductID, AVG(OrderQty) AS AverageOrderQuantityFROM Sales.SalesOrderDetailGROUP BY ProductID;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  1. Selecting Columns:

    • The SELECT clause specifies the columns to include in the output:
      • ProductID: To identify each product.
      • AVG(OrderQty) AS AverageOrderQuantity: To calculate the average order quantity for each product and give it a descriptive alias.

  2. Grouping Data:

    • The GROUP BY ProductID clause instructs the database to group the results by ProductID, ensuring that the average order quantity is calculated separately for each unique product.

  3. Aggregating Order Quantity:

    • The AVG(OrderQty) function performs the average calculation within each product group.

Key Points:

  • Schema Specification: Ensure you include the correct schema name ("Sales" in this case) as part of the table name if necessary based on your database platform.
  • Grouping Importance: The GROUP BY clause is essential for getting average values for each product. Without it, you"d get a single average for the entire table.
  • Column Selection: You can add other columns from the "SalesOrderDetail" table to the SELECT clause if you need additional information alongside the average order quantity.

I"m ready to assist with any further SQL tasks you may have on the AdventureWorks2012 database!

Q: 20. Join the "Product" and "SalesOrderDetail" tables to display product information along with order details.
A:
Here"s the SQL query to join the "Product" and "SalesOrderDetail" tables, displaying product information along with order details:

SQL
SELECT p.Name AS ProductName,        p.ProductNumber,        p.Color,        p.ListPrice,        sod.SalesOrderID,        sod.OrderQty,        sod.LineTotalFROM Production.Product pJOIN Sales.SalesOrderDetail sod ON p.ProductID = sod.ProductID;
Use code with caution. Learn more

Explanation:

  1. Joining Tables:

    • The FROM clause lists the two tables to be joined: Production.Product (aliased as "p") and Sales.SalesOrderDetail (aliased as "sod").
    • The JOIN clause specifies the condition for linking the tables: p.ProductID = sod.ProductID. This matches rows where the ProductID values in both tables are equal, effectively associating product information with corresponding order details.

  2. Selecting Columns:

    • The SELECT clause specifies the columns to retrieve, using aliases for clarity:
      • p.Name AS ProductName: The product name.
      • p.ProductNumber: The product number.
      • p.Color: The product color (optional, can be removed if not needed).
      • p.ListPrice: The product"s list price.
      • sod.SalesOrderID: The sales order ID.
      • sod.OrderQty: The quantity ordered for each product.
      • sod.LineTotal: The total price for each line item (product quantity multiplied by price).

Key Points:

  • Schema Specification: Ensure you replace the schema names (Production and Sales) if they differ in your database platform.
  • Column Customization: You can adjust the selected columns or add other relevant ones as needed.
  • Join Condition: The ON clause in the JOIN statement is crucial for connecting the tables correctly based on shared values.

Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or need help with other SQL tasks in the AdventureWorks2012 database!
